item.title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time Remake press kits seemingly included a collectible dagger, further cementing just how darn close the game was to r
item.content:encoded:
It appears that the press kit for Ubisoft's cancelled Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time Remake would have included a collectible dagger.

A video which allegedly shows off this collectible was recently shared online, with the dagger being unpacked from a wooden box with Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time Remake markings.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

The purported Sands of Time dagger itself, meanwhile, featured a golden painted hilt and iridescent resin-looking blade (thanks, IGN). As well as the dagger, this unboxing video (which you can see below) included a display stand within the box, which again had the game's name written across it in gold writing.

While this dagger is, for now, only an alleged collectible for Ubisoft's Sands of Time remake, which would have been part of the press Kit sent out to media, many have said its reported existence shows just how close the Prince of Persia team was to releasing its game.

As a reminder, Ubisoft's Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time Remake was unveiled in 2020, but suffered numerous delays and setbacks since. This included the game seemingly being rebooted from scratch in 2023. However, it seemed the great wait was coming to an end, as towards the end of last year, Ubisoft itself had its Sands of Time Remake slated for release during"Q4" of the current financial year, which comes to an end on 31st March. So, in just a couple of months.

Alas, it wasn't to be, though, and last month Ubisoft announced a "major organisational, operational and portfolio reset", which saw the company delay seven unspecified projects, close two studios and cancel multiple games including its Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time Remake.

Eurogamer has Ubisoft for comment on the alleged Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time press kit.

Soon after Ubisoft announced its company reset, the team behind Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time's embattled remake shared a few words of its own, acknowledging the cancellation was "deeply disappointing" for fans. However, it was keen to stress this "does not mean [its] stepping away from the franchise" for good.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/prince-of-persia-the-sands-of-time-remake-press-kits-seemingly-included-a-collectible-dagger-further-cementing-just-how-darn-close-the-game-was-to-release

item.title: Civilization 7 solidifies its course-correction plans with massive expansion-sized spring update
item.content:encoded:
Civilization 7 was a bit of an odd release last year. With a Metacritic score of 79 and positive comments from Take-Two's leadership, it was considered a success. Longtime Firaxis fans weren't as kind to it though, as many felt it was too disruptive or shallow. As expected, 2026 might be the year the studio makes the game's future brighter.

I'm saying it was to be expected because we've been here before. Civilization 5 and 6 also faced heavy criticism upon release, before going on to become stone-cold 4X classics of the modern era. Long story short: Firaxis likes to experiment, whereas Civilization diehards are allergic to big shakeups... at least at first. Now, following a number of quick reworks and hot patches (as well as fun DLCs), Civilization 7's future is coming into focus, and it's looking a lot brighter than we expected.

On 2nd February, 2K and Firaxis shared their vision for the seventh game in the series as it enters 2026. It all starts with Update 1.3.2, which is "going live soon" even if we've got zero words on a specific date yet. The tentative list of changes and additions is long, but players can expect nested tooltips, balance passes across more civs like the French Empire and the Mughal, and reworks of AI diplomacy, coastal raids, and the Appeal system. Moreover, the "legendary demigod of Uruk, Gilgamesh" is coming as a thank-you gift for free.

Further into 2026 (spring is the current target), a batch of deep-cut changes are coming with a huge expansion-sized update called 'Test of Time' which aims to heavily redesign the flow of the entire game and all end goals. The community will be invited to playtest these bigger changes through the Firaxis Feature Workshop, but we've got a quick rundown of what you can expect if you're waiting for the final release. And you can watch the video version below:

First, players will be able to play as a single civilization throughout the entire game, offering a traditional alternative to the "dynamic empire-building experience" of vanilla Civilization 7. Of course, reworks will be happening to accommodate such a radical extra, with a system called Syncretism that allows to "create all-new builds" that borrow from other civilizations once per age without burying the original one.

Victories are getting a top-to-bottom rework as well; Legacy Paths are less important now, and victories can be achieved earlier and by completing "a wide range of different activities" that should make both short and long-term competition more flexible and engaging. In fact, Legacy Paths as we knew them will be binned, with Triumphs taking over. They're themed achievements of sorts that reward civilizations with bonuses and "cards" that can be used when an age starts.

Needless to say, that's a lot to digest, and we're not expecting all these changes to land from the get-go when they're out, but it's exciting to see Firaxis turn Civilization 7 into a game that bridges the gap between newcomers and veterans without erasing its original vision.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/civilization-7-developer-firaxis-details-2026-reworks-free-updates
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Sorry Dispatch fans, there's "no possibility" of an uncensored physical version on Switch
item.content:encoded:
AdHoc has said there is "no possibility" of an uncensored physical version of its superhero workplace comedy Dispatch on Switch or Switch 2.

Last week, fans were disappointed to discover Dispatch was heavily censored on Switch and Switch 2 as standard, with characters' nipples and penises covered with a black box by default, while noises of sexual pleasure were dampened down.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Soon after AdHoc announced Dispatch was censored on Switch consoles, Nintendo released its own statement on the issue, saying the company "requires all games on its platforms to receive ratings from independent organisations and to meet our established content and platform guidelines".

Since then, AdHoc said it understood why its fans were "pissed", and it is now working with Nintendo "on a path forward". The Dispatch studio added that while it "can't make any specific promises just yet", it is "confident we'll be able to push an update to address at least some of the censored content", albeit in several weeks' time due to the console submission process.

However, even with that being said, an uncensored Switch and Switch 2 physical version is not possible, according to a statement shared with GoNintendo. AdHoc added the discussion isn't "currently relevant as there are no announcements regarding a physical release at this time", despite previously hinting it would like to see a physical release of Dispatch.

GoNintendo also asked about the singular worldwide release discussion which has started to make the rounds following Dispatch's Switch censorship discussion. The publication got the following response back from AdHoc's PR: "AdHoc is legally unable to provide further comment on why separate SKUs were not possible for different regions."

Despite this recent blip in public favour, Dispatch has been a huge success for AdHoc, and sold over 1m copies in just 10 days following its initial release last year.

Thanks to this success, the studio is now considering a second season, possibly with even more sex scenes given the "ravenous" response to the first season.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/sorry-dispatch-fans-theres-no-possibility-of-an-uncensored-physical-version-on-switch
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: As player numbers fall, Highguard makes the actually-quite-good 5v5 mode permanent
item.content:encoded:
Barely over a month in, 2026 has been busy, but Highguard is easily the strangest game release we've had so far. Following a baffling, nearly marketing-free rollout following its reveal at The Game Awards 2025, it crashed into a wall of negative reviews, but developer Wildlight Entertainment was quick to react. Now, the sentiment is more positive following 5v5 matches being tested and locked - but can it survive the poisoned conversation that's sprung up around the game so far?

Ahead of the last weekend, a first patch addressed some of the most pressing criticisms, with the devs also deciding to experiment with a limited-time 5v5 mode that could maybe make Highguard's large maps feel less empty outside the attack and defence phases. It turns out that was a good call, as the Steam reviews have now climbed up to "Mixed" as players (the hopeful ones, at least) engage with a more frenetic and brutal version of the shooter. Thus, the 5v5 queue is staying.

Of course, the conversation on social media and YouTube is far more negative, with the usual suspects using the latest big attempt at breaking into the live-service space as a punching bag instead of downvoting and moving on. There's a conversation worth having about the industry reaching peak live-service critical mass years ago, sure, but don't expect grifters to approach any game making waves in good faith.

That said, the reality of the situation is that Highguard is struggling after a confusing launch and due to its objectively under-cooked state. There's a few too many different shooters in that esports-oriented mix, and not all of them work or play well together. The 5v5 mode is promising in that it actually feels good to play and makes you catch a glimpse of what the game could become in the long run. That is, if there's a long run for it. We know Wildlight worked on a full-year roadmap for Highguard, but can the game really sustain itself for so long?

The game's SteamDB profile paints a grim picture, at least on PC, with the concurrent players chart steadily going down since Highguard opened its gates on 26th January. 3,157 players are inside the game at the time of writing, with 8,404 at its 24-hour peak. Positive reviews are up, yes, and even surpassing the negative ones now, but these numbers aren't what you want to see only a week after launch when you're thinking big with another online shooter.

We don't have access to the data on consoles yet, but so far, the crossplay capabilities are ensuring that matchmaking is quick, so there might be a bigger interest there that we can't quantify. In my personal case, I'm now curious about where it could go following the 5v5 update, but having been burned in the past a few too many times by similar shooters, I'm also staying realistic.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/highguard-gets-permanent-5v5-mode
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Switch finally surpasses the Nintendo DS to become company's best-selling console, ever
item.content:encoded:
The Nintendo Switch has surpassed the DS to become the company's best selling console ever.

As shared in Nintendo's latest financial report, which covers the first nine months of FY2026 up until 31st December 2025, the Switch has now sold 155.37m units. To compare, the company's previous best selling console - the Nintendo DS - has clocked up 154.02m units sold as of 31st December 2025.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

3.25m Switch units were sold during the nine-month period covered in Nintendo's latest financial report, which began on 1st April 2025.

Nintendo's Switch console is now the second best selling console of all time, only behind that of the PlayStation 2. Back in 2024, Sony confirmed its PS2 console - which first released back in March 2000 - had shifted 160m units since its millennium launch.

Meanwhile, Nintendo's Switch 2 has sold 17.37m units as of 31st December 2025, with the company adding its latest console had got off to a "good start" on its release in June. The Switch 2 is Nintendo's fastest-selling dedicated video game platform.

As for Switch 2 software sales, Mario Kart World has sold 14.03m units, Donkey Kong Bananza has sold 4.25m units, Pokemon Legends: Z-A - Nintendo Switch 2 Edition has sold 3.89m units and Kirby Air Riders has sold 1.76m units.

Looking at the coming weeks, Nintendo is set to release Mario Tennis Fever in February, and then Pok√©mon Pokopia will be arriving in March.

Mario Tennis Fever promises 38 characters - the most in the series' history apparently - plus a range of different activities, online options, and an adventure mode starring the Mario babies.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/switch-finally-surpasses-the-nintendo-ds-to-become-companys-best-selling-console-ever
